awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Fully-Motorized Research Microscope at Fairfield University Project Description
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Fairfield University to fund an automated research microscope. This instrument enables projects that require detailed observations of subcellular structures, real-time imaging, and three-dimensional reconstructions of thick tissues. These sophisticated imaging techniques will be incorporated into the biology lab coursework for undergraduate science majors at Fairfield University. In addition science majors that do independent research with faculty will have access to state-of-the-art technology that both empowers their research and serves as a crucial training tool. Fairfield University has a long-standing commitment to promote science education for high school students from underserved communities through BASE Camp, a program that brings high school girls to the Fairfield University campus for summer research experiences. BASE camp students will also use this microscope in their research projects. The ability to capture detailed images of otherwise invisible subjects is awe-inspiring to students of all ages, and increases the impact of research experience on education and on attitudes toward science.

A staggering breadth of research on the Fairfield campus will benefit from this instrument. It will be used to study how Candida albicans, a pathogenic fungus, constructs a biofilm and will enable researchers to visualize real-time responses to agents that disrupt biofilms. In addition it will be used to observe the subcellular localization of engineered enzymes that fluoresce upon activation. The microscope is a versatile instrument that is capable of capturing three-dimensional images of large complex organs such as the gonad in live C. elegans nematode worms. Researchers will use the C. elegans gonad to study how the regulation of microtubule motors impacts architecture of an intricate tissue. The microscope will also be used to study human cells. For example in one study users will examine how lipid raft distribution responds to dietary intervention in ex vivo peripheral blood mononuclear cells. In a different study, researchers will monitor a human cancer cell line's response to potential anti-cancer agents. These inquiries traverse the fields of genetics, development, biochemistry, metabolism, microbiology, and cancer biology, and will lead to exciting discoveries and new research trajectories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fairfield University used NSF funds to purchase a research-grade wide-field epifluorescent microscope. The funded instrument has features that enable multiple projects on our campus. For example, its fluorescence capacity, automated stage, sensitive camera, and structured illumination capability allowed us to capture the details of oocyte maturation in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans. This enabled characterization of differences between low-fertility mutants and wild-type animals. We used antibodies to fluorescently label several markers of oocyte maturity, and then used the funded microscope to image the stained animals. The photos collected were so clear that we could count individual chromosomes and see nucleoli within the maturing oocytes. We found that mutants aberrantly retained nucleoli in oocytes that should have been mature. Those same oocytes failed to accumulate a phosphorylated histone marker usually associated with mature oocytes. These observations support the idea that our mutants have defects in oocyte maturity, which could explain the low fertility phenotype. We published this work in microPublication Biology in 2021.

 

The instrument was also used in a different project with the goal of developing noninvasive methods for diagnosing breast cancer. In this project, MCF10 and MCF10AT cell lines were characterized using phase-contrast microscopy to study morphological changes under various conditions. In addition, differences in autofluoresence of FAD and NADH were studied, and the microscope was able to detect changes that correlated with the growth rates of the cells and their response to the chemotherapy agent adriamycin. This work is promising in that it identifies targets for imaging that could make it easier to diagnose breast cancer. This work is the basis of an abstract that will be submitted to the AACR meeting in April 2023.

 

Developing projects with the instrument include characterizing sperm defects in a C. elegans mutant, studying how brain morphology changes in socially-isolated rats, imaging tripeptide influence carbon nanotube autofluoresence, and capturing early embryonc development in live nematodes carrying fluorescent markers. The multiple capabilities of the microscope make possible many projects spanning several different fields.

 

In addition to enabling the pursuit of exciting science, the instrument has provided a fantastic opportunity for students to use sophisticated research equipment for their projects. Multiple students from several laboratories have used the instrument to pursue their own research questions. The instrument was also used in a Developmental Biology class activity, in which students captured images of their immunolocalizations using the microscope. A high school student came to campus and designed her own project, using the instrument and its software to study and measure the effects of computer light on animal development. The instrument has proved to be an accessible and powerful tool that has broadened the types of questions we can address on our campus and enabled students to address such questions at early stages in their careers.
